Package com.google.inject.tools.suite

Tools for using guice.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
GuiceToolsModule.CodeRunnerFactory  
GuiceToolsModule.ModuleManagerFactory  
JavaManager Represents a project in the user's code.
Messenger Responsible for displaying messages to the user in dialog box format.
ProblemsHandler Notify the user in realtime of problems with their guice code by code assist or other (nonblocking) means.
ProgressHandler The ProgressHandler is responsible for displaying a progress bar or other indicator to the user during long operations.
ProgressHandler.ProgressStep Represents a single step in a task managed by a progress bar.
 

Class Summary
BlockingProgressHandler An implementation of ProgressHandler that does nothing to display the progress and blocks the calling thread while it runs.
DefaultJavaManager Implementation of the JavaManager that assumes everything is on the default classpath and that uses the default java on the system.
DefaultMessenger Implementation of the Messenger that does nothing.
GuiceToolsModule The guice module controlling the tools suite.
 

Package com.google.inject.tools.suite Description

Tools for using guice.

The tools suite is the infrastructure for writing guice tools, such as IDE plugins.

To use the tools suite, simply extend the GuiceToolsModule to a concrete set of bindings and then use guice to inject a ModuleManager in your code.

The JavaManager, ProblemsHandler, ProgressHandler and Messenger should also be implemented and bound in a subclass of GuiceToolsModule that should be used for the injections. If they are not bound the defaults are:

JavaManager
java manager that assumes everything is on the default classpath
ProblemsHandler
problems handler that ignores problems
Messenger
messenger that ignores messages
ProgressHandler
progress handler that blocks the current thread and displays nothing

The basic objects in our tool suite are:

ModuleManager
manages the modules in the user's code
ProblemsHandler
notifies the user of guice related problems in the code
CodeRunner
runs CodeSnippets in user space to resolve bindings

There is also the snippets package which is packaged a standalone jar file that needs to be on the classpath provided by the JavaManager.
